title: Quotation of the Day: On Juneteenth, Tulsa Pairs Joy With Defiance
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, June 20, 2020.
content: “We’re celebrating the emancipation of slaves, but we’re really celebrating the idea of being black. We love it and we love us.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 20, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, June 20, 2020.
content: An article on Thursday about the Chinese government’s effort to collect DNA samples from males across China misstated comments from Dr. Zhong Chang, a researcher at the U.S. firm Thermo Fisher. When speaking about genetic testing kits the company was marketing to Chinese law enforcement, Dr. Zhong said the kits are calibrated so that they can effectively gather DNA information from China’s ethnic minorities like Uighurs and Tibetans, not that they could distinguish ethnic minorities from other groups. (A spokesman for Thermo Fisher said the kits lack that capability.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Newly Released Mueller Report With Fewer Redactions
description: New details from the Justice Department’s inquiry into Russian influence over the 2016 election released on Friday underscored President Trump’s keen interest in weaponizing information stolen by the Russians and funneled to WikiLeaks for use against his 2016 opponent, Hillary Clinton.
content: New details from the Justice Department’s inquiry into Russian influence over the 2016 election released on Friday underscored President Trump’s keen interest in weaponizing information stolen by the Russians and funneled to WikiLeaks for use against his 2016 opponent, Hillary Clinton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Treasury Dept. Agrees to Release Data on Small-Business Relief
description: The decision to reveal who received a Paycheck Protection Program loan comes after weeks of backlash over a lack of transparency.
content: WASHINGTON — Bowing to political pressure, the Trump administration said on Friday evening that it would disclose borrower information for recipients of millions of small-business loans through the $660 billion Paycheck Protection Program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Hall
title: Summer Solstice 2020 and the Search for Life in the Galaxy
description: As you mark the longest day of the year, consider the debate among astronomers over whether Earth’s tilt toward the sun helps make life on our world and others possible.
content: On the summer solstice this Saturday, the Northern Hemisphere will dip toward the sun and bathe in direct sunlight for longer than any other day of the year. That will cause the sun to rise early, climb high into the sky — sweeping far above city skylines or mountain peaks — and set late into the evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: The Red Sox Organist Is Providing All the Baseball You Need Right Now
description: With baseball shut down, Josh Kantor isn’t playing at Fenway Park. To fill the void, he plays a concert online every afternoon.
content: People throughout the sports world, from athletes to arena staff, tell The New York Times how their lives have changed during the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: ‘Voguing Has Always Been a Protest’
description: The ballroom community has vogued its way through decades of change and social unrest. But 2020 has meant more changes than ever before. Here’s why.
content: The ballroom community has vogued its way through decades of change and social unrest. But 2020 has meant more changes than ever before. Here’s why.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: What to Know About the Tulsa Greenwood Massacre
description: As many as 300 people were killed in 1921 when a white mob attacked the Greenwood district of Tulsa, a thriving black community, and burned it to the ground.
content: On May 30, 1921, the Greenwood district of Tulsa, Okla., was a thriving black community: a rarity in an era of lynchings, segregation and a rapidly growing Ku Klux Klan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Animal Crossings
description: Byron and Harrison Walden collaborate with a bunch of wild and crazy creatures.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Happy Father’s Day, everybody! Today’s grid is a collaboration between Byron Walden — a college professor and veteran constructor — and his 8-year-old son, Harrison. Harrison has been solving puzzles most of his life, and construction is certainly in his stars. Long before he was even a twinkle, his parents commemorated the day of their nuptials by collaborating on a theme puzzle (explanatory Wordplay column here).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tacey Rychter
title: How the Pandemic Has Affected Passports, Global Entry, T.S.A. PreCheck and More
description: Travel is gradually returning, but not without disruptions. Here’s what to expect when applying for official travel documents and membership in security programs.
content: After three months of travel at a near-standstill, restrictions are slowly lifting and travelers are venturing out again. On Sunday, the Transportation Security Administration screened more than 544,000 people, a daily record since traveler numbers plummeted in late March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: Trump’s ‘What Do You Have to Lose?’ Presidency Is Rallying Again
description: As an encapsulation of the president’s worldview, some former associates say, there is perhaps no beating the text of a campaign waiver: “guests voluntarily assume all risks.”
content: Supporting President Trump — or even taking him at his word — has always been an exercise in risk tolerance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni, Astead W. Herndon and Katie Glueck
title: What to Watch For at Trump’s Tulsa Campaign Rally
description: Will the thousands of Trump supporters wear masks? What time is the rally? How will President Trump talk about race? What protests will he face? Here’s what you need to know.
content: TULSA, Okla. — President Trump is determined to try to have a political comeback rally in spite of the devastating health and economic crises that have unfolded on his watch, as well as the nationwide protests against racism that have left him on the defensive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bonnie Tsui
title: How to Share Your Backyard Pool
description: Even in a pandemic you can still invite friends over for a safe swim. And go ahead, hog the pool float.
content: In a normal summer, having friends over for a swim is one of the easy joys for people fortunate enough to have a backyard pool. Now, it can feel fraught, even as water-lovers everywhere are desperate for aquatic relief with the closure of many public pools. But experts say it is possible to share your oasis safely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adriana Balsamo
title: Turn Your Trash Into Art
description: You’ll need newspaper, glue, paints and creativity.
content: One question that you’ve most likely asked yourself thanks to spending so much time at home is, “How do I go through so many containers?” Hollie Velten-Lattrell, who runs a creative design studio in Maplewood, N.J., can’t exactly answer that. But she does have an innovative way to repurpose your empty cans, toilet paper rolls and old newspapers: by making a “junk vessel.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Tempting of Neil Gorsuch
description: Another conservative justice’s arc bends toward juristocracy.
content: It might surprise contemporary Americans that for most of our history, what we call “culture war” debates — arguments about rights, social justice, the moral organization of society — were often settled through democratic deliberation, rather than the kind of ruling the Supreme Court just delivered on gay and transgender civil rights. Congress debated and passed laws. State legislatures did the same. Constitutional amendments were proposed, passed, ratified — and when necessary, repealed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ishmael Reed
title: America’s Criminal Justice System and Me
description: Throughout my life, I have had frightening, maddening and absurd encounters with police officers.
content: Every black southern family that I’m aware of has a cold case. The murder of a family member by a white man about which records might have disappeared or been deleted. It’s family oral tradition that keeps the story alive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxane Gay
title: How We Save Ourselves
description: I want this time to be different and there are moments when I think it might be.
content: Corporations finally believe black lives matter. Or they at least understand that they have to make it look like they believe black lives matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: In Kentucky, Racial Justice Movement Transforms Quest to Oust McConnell
description: Amy McGrath was considered a safe bet in the Democratic primary. But the recent movement for racial justice has elevated the candidacy of her African-American rival, Charles Booker, in the race to defeat Mitch McConnell.
content: LEXINGTON, Ky. — Senate Democrats thought they had it all planned out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Jack Healy
title: Protesters Demanded Police Reform. Minnesota Lawmakers Left Without Passing a Bill.
description: The Democratic-led House and Republican-led Senate, which had approved competing plans, failed to compromise before a weeklong special session ended.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Political leaders in Minnesota promised sweeping changes after George Floyd’s killing turned their state into a focal point for nationwide fury and grief over police killings and racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: From Policing to Climate Change, a Sweeping Call for a ‘Moral Revolution’
description: A coalition modeled after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s Poor People’s Campaign released an ambitious agenda to help the working poor fight systemic racism and inequality.
content: A national coalition to address the challenges of the working poor released a sweeping legislative platform in a three-hour virtual rally on Saturday, including proposals to address mass incarceration, health care and wealth inequality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Family of Black Man Found Hanging Says Death Was by Suicide
description: Malcolm Harsch was one of two black men whose bodies were found hanging from trees in California cities in recent weeks.
content: When the authorities suggested that two black men whose bodies were found hanging from trees in two Southern California cities had died by suicide, many community activists did not buy it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Who Can Fire a Court-Appointed U.S. Attorney? An Abrupt Legal Fight, Explained
description: The top federal prosecutor in Manhattan had refused to let the attorney general fire him, but acquiesced after William P. Barr invoked the president.
content: WASHINGTON — The declaration by the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan on Friday night that he would stay in his job despite Attorney General William P. Barr’s attempt to fire him raised not just the mystery of what was behind Mr. Barr’s move, but also a legal question: Who has the authority to remove him?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Crowd Is Sparse as Trump Tries to Reignite Campaign
description: Speaking in Tulsa, Okla., a day after the Juneteenth holiday, the president mocked the coronavirus that has killed 121,000 Americans and claimed he wanted to slow down testing.
content: This briefing has ended. Read more about President Trump’s Tulsa rally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Judge Rejects Trump Request for Order Blocking Bolton’s Memoir
description: But the judge also sharply criticized the former national security adviser, suggesting his $2 million book advance may be in jeopardy.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s former national security adviser John R. Bolton can go forward with the publication of his memoir, a federal judge ruled on Saturday, rejecting the administration’s request for an order that he try to pull the book back and saying it was too late for such an order to succeed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: The Walls of the Church Couldn’t Keep the Trump Era Out
description: The young pastor wasn’t sure his congregation would like what he had to say and had no idea where it would lead all of them. He found himself at a crossroads of God, Alabama and Donald Trump.
content: WILLIAMS, Ala. — In early 2017, a pastor in the Alabama countryside named Chris Thomas prepared to give his Sunday sermon. President Trump had been inaugurated the week before, and the new administration was already making headlines with a travel ban that included refugees from Syria.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Florida and South Carolina Again Set Records as U.S. Coronavirus Cases Surge
description: Southern officials warn of new clusters linked to bars and frat parties. Health officials feared the Trump campaign rally in Tulsa, Okla., could be a “superspreader” event. Workers in Japan have avoided the mass layoffs seen in other countries.
content: For the third straight day, Florida and South Carolina broke their single-day records for new cases, while infection levels for Missouri and Nevada also reached new highs on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Questions Surround Police Killing of Latino Man in California
description: Andres Guardado, 18, was killed after showing a weapon and fleeing deputies, according to the authorities. His family said he worked as a security guard.
content: Activists and family members of an 18-year-old Latino man are calling his death in Southern California this week an unjustified police killing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Shaila Dewan
title: After George Floyd, Fresh Scrutiny of Old Cases
description: In the wake of outrage over Mr. Floyd’s death, several deadly episodes involving the police are receiving renewed attention.
content: ATLANTA — The story of Elijah McClain’s death, which came after he was confronted and detained by police officers last year in the Denver suburb of Aurora, Colo., did not go unnoticed by residents and the local news media in the weeks that followed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Tens of Thousands Protest in Mali Amid Growing Opposition to Keita Presidency
description: The unrest underscored the mounting opposition to President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita, who has led Mali since 2013.
content: BAMAKO, Mali — Police fired tear gas at protesters demanding President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita’s resignation on Friday as tens of thousands took to the streets for the second time this month in Mali’s capital, Bamako.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Performing Well
description: Stella Zawistowski drops into her Saturday groove.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I listened to this album (spoiler at that link!) in the background while I worked on this post. It’s the seed entry to Stella Zawistowski’s second Saturday puzzle for The Times, and it’s wonderfully lush and romantic. There’s a lot of rhythm and action in this grid. I made a couple of missteps, but it wasn’t too difficult to get swept up in the music and float over and through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Pence Won’t Say the Words ‘Black Lives Matter’ in an Interview
description: On Juneteenth, a holiday that honors the end of slavery in America, the vice president said that “all lives matter’’ but twice declined to say that black lives matter.
content: WASHINGTON — Vice President Mike Pence twice refused to say that “black lives matter” during an interview on a Philadelphia television station on Friday, insisting instead that “all lives matter in a very real sense.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Black Tulsans Reflect on Legacy of the 1921 Massacre
description: The massacre on Greenwood Avenue, the site of one of America’s worst racist attacks, still has a significant impact on the residents of Tulsa, Okla.
content: The massacre on Greenwood Avenue, the site of one of America’s worst racist attacks, still has a significant impact on the residents of Tulsa, Okla.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Blackall
title: ‘I’m Here,’ Outside Says. ‘I Miss You.’
description: For children who have been indoors for a long time, these five picture books about the wonders of the natural world will be a breath of fresh air.
content: I spent most of my childhood outside, climbing trees and wading through creeks with my brother in the South Australian bush. We rarely went barefoot, for fear of bindi grass, like shards of glass. We shook out our boots for fear of funnel-web, redback and huntsman spiders. We never sat down without checking first for snakes, and always kept an eye on the sky for bombarding magpies. As my Brooklyn-raised son once said, the Australian outdoors is beautiful but it sort of wants to kill you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Can Gay Bars, an Anchor of N.Y.C. Nightlife, Survive the Pandemic?
description: June is Pride Month, but high rents and little-to-no income mean establishments including the Stonewall Inn are “facing an uncertain future.”
content: Protesters have returned to the Stonewall Inn again and again in recent weeks to demand an end to police brutality, raising their fists, taking a knee and holding moments of silence on the same ground where a riot in 1969 helped spark the modern gay rights movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Paolo Giorgio Ferri, Hunter of Looted Antiquities, Dies at 72
description: A prosecutor in Italy, he dismantled multinational trafficking rings, recovering tens of thousands of Greco-Roman artifacts worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
content: When the Italian prosecutor Paolo Giorgio Ferri visited the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 2004, he posed for a picture beside an ancient terra cotta mixing bowl so rare and celebrated that it had held pride of place in the Met’s Greek and Roman galleries for 32 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: David Sedaris, Dressed Up With Nowhere to Go
description: With two books in the works but all plans on hold, the writer is pacing New York City and destroying his Fitbit friends.
content: When New York went into lockdown, David Sedaris settled into his apartment on the Upper East Side and canceled his 45-city book tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: 6 Books to Help You Grasp How We Got to This Moment
description: The current protests are unprecedented in their number, scope and impact, but their newness is built on a long past, one that scholars have grappled with for decades.
content: No book can provide a full understanding of the complex pain and enduring injustice that is the recent wave of countrywide protests. But books can provide context and texture, and memoirs and sociology texts by black writers have been flying off the shelves. So have history books.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jake Halpern
title: My 11-Year-Old Came Up With a Better Government
description: My children used to like reading about dystopias. But now we’re living in one.
content: For the last few months, my 11-year-old son, Lucian, has been busy creating his own planet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carina Ray
title: ‘Could the Police Kill Me, Too?’ My Young Son Asked Me
description: I knew I had to be honest.
content: “If I go, could they kill me too?” my 9-year-old son asked. His question hung in the air like thick fog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Iliana Magra
title: Stabbing at U.K. Park Leaves 3 Dead
description: The attack was in a park in southern England where a Black Lives Matter protest had been held earlier in the day. The police arrested a man on suspicion of murder and said it was not being investigated as an act of terrorism.
content: LONDON — Three people were killed and several injured on Saturday in a stabbing attack at a park in southern England where a Black Lives Matter protest had been held earlier in the day, according to the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess
title: Jay Clayton, Low-Profile Regulator, Is Catapulted Into a Political Fight
description: Amid a muted tenure at the S.E.C., the corporate lawyer is now the Trump administration’s intended nominee to be the top prosecutor for the Southern District of New York.
content: After three years at the helm of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Jay Clayton had made it known to colleagues, friends and the Trump administration that he was itching to go back to New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Katie Benner, Ben Protess, Maggie Haberman, William K. Rashbaum, Nicole Hong and Benjamin Weiser
title: Trump Fires U.S. Attorney in New York Who Investigated His Inner Circle
description: The president’s move heightened criticism that he was purging his administration of officials whose independence could be a threat to his re-election.
content: President Trump on Saturday fired the federal prosecutor whose office put his former personal lawyer in prison and is investigating his current one, heightening criticism that the president was carrying out an extraordinary purge to rid his administration of officials whose independence could be a threat to his re-election campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear, Maggie Haberman and Astead W. Herndon
title: Trump Rally Fizzles as Attendance Falls Short of Campaign’s Expectations
description: President Trump’s attempt to revive his re-election bid sputtered badly as he traveled to Tulsa for his first mass rally in months but found a small crowd and delivered a disjointed speech.
content: TULSA, Okla. — President Trump’s attempt to revive his re-election campaign sputtered badly on Saturday night as he traveled to Tulsa for his first mass rally in months and found a far smaller crowd than his aides had promised him, then delivered a disjointed speech that did not address the multiple crises facing the nation or scandals battering him in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: Federal Agency Halts Studies of Hydroxychloroquine, Drug Trump Promoted
description: The National Institutes of Health decided to stop one trial because the drug was unlikely to benefit patients, and another because not enough people enrolled.
content: The National Institutes of Health said Saturday that it had stopped two clinical trials of hydroxychloroquine, the malaria drug that President Trump promoted to treat and prevent the coronavirus, one because the drug was unlikely to be effective and the other because not enough patients signed up to participate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Joni Ernst and Donald Trump Could Both Be in Trouble in Iowa
description: Iowa seemed out of reach for Democrats not too long ago. Now, the presidential race appears to be tightening, and Senator Ernst, a Republican, is facing a strong challenge from a political newcomer.
content: Iowa was not on anyone’s bingo card of 2020 battlegrounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Babyteeth’ and ‘The Great American Groom-A-Long’
description: Eliza Scanlen stars in a new coming-of-age drama, and Carson Kressley hosts a special aimed at helping pet owners groom from home.
content: BABYTEETH (2019) Rent or buy on Amazon, Google Play, iTunes, Vudu, YouTube and pay TV operators. What if, at 16, you knew your first love could also possibly be your last? That’s the question at the heart of this family drama, which stars Eliza Scanlen as Milla, a teenager grappling with the onset of a serious, and possibly terminal, illness. As Milla’s parents (played by Ben Mendelsohn and Essie Davis) struggle to deal with their daughter’s diagnosis, they become even more alarmed when Milla brings home Moses (Toby Wallace), a homeless and drug addled 23-year-old. “He proves to be a prince in greasy threads,” Manohla Dargis writes in her review for The New York Times. “A sad-boy fantasy who proves as pure-hearted as Milla, or rather as the story needs him to be.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: Posting a Black Square, but Not Black Faces
description: On social media, many travel companies were quick to proclaim their support for the Black Lives Matter movement, but some have been criticized for a history of leaving black people out.
content: Travel and travel planning are being disrupted by the worldwide spread of the coronavirus. For the latest updates, read The New York Times’s Covid-19 coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 2 Sentenced to House Arrest in Long-Running Scheme to Steal Rare Books
description: The board chair of the Carnegie Library of Pittsburgh said the thefts “will forever raise doubts about the security of all future charitable donations, particularly to the Carnegie Library.”
content: A former archivist and a bookstore owner who were accused of stealing about 300 rare books and other artifacts from Pittsburgh’s central library — items that would cost more than $8 million to replace — were each sentenced Friday to several years of house arrest, prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Brockman
title: Creating Portfolios That Are ‘Not for the Faint of Heart’
description: Savers who want to build their nest eggs without relying solely on the stock market have other options. The pandemic is testing their skills.
content: Audrey Smith knows what’s it like to plant a seed and watch it grow. One of 11 children, she worked in the fields of her family’s farm in Texarkana, Ark., and ate vegetables they grew.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Koeze and Denise Lu
title: The N.Y.P.D. Spends $6 Billion a Year. Proposals to Defund It Want to Cut $1 Billion.
description: As calls to defund the police grow around the country, public officials and advocacy groups have proposed major cuts to the nation’s largest and most expensive police force.
content: As calls to defund the police grow around the country, public officials and advocacy groups have proposed major cuts to the nation’s largest and most expensive police force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon warn us, caveat lector!
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s puzzle is one of those where the passage itself makes a great impression and recommends the book itself (we take brilliant cluing for granted with Team Cox/Rathvon, but not every end result is so vibrant). The book is “Curious Behavior,” by Robert R. Provine, and it concerns all manner of hiccups, yawns, sneezes and other reflexive emanations, including laughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Baloue
title: Voguing for Our Lives. Again.
description: “We shouldn’t be screaming, ‘Trans Lives Matter,’ but we have to,” said Leiomy Maldonado, a ballroom icon. “We’re strong and we’re here to fight.”
content: Earlier this year, videos emerged of members of the ballroom community voguing in hazmat suits, holding “kiki” battles via TikTok and creating hand washing tutorials with new coronavirus-inspired beats and chants. Then came the videos of members cat walking with protesters, dropping into “dips” in front of police cars, voguing at impromptu protest balls and marching the asphalt runway while holding Black Lives Matter signs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: NASCAR’s Confederate Flag Ban Faces a Test in Alabama
description: Sunday’s race at Talladega Superspeedway will come after a black, Alabama-born driver took on a stubborn ritual of racing and Southern culture.
content: ATLANTA — Mike Harmon has spent much of his life driving the stock-car courses of the South, which also means that he has spent much of his life speeding past Confederate flags.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ella Koeze and Denise Lu
title: The N.Y.P.D. Spends $6 Billion a Year. Proposals to Defund It Want to Cut $1 Billion.
description: As calls to defund the police grow around the country, public officials and advocacy groups have proposed major cuts to the nation’s largest and most expensive police force.
content: As calls to defund the police grow around the country, public officials and advocacy groups have proposed major cuts to the nation’s largest and most expensive police force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser, William K. Rashbaum, Nicole Hong, Maggie Haberman and Katie Benner
title: Clash Over U.S. Attorney Who Investigated Trump Associates Sets Off Crisis
description: Attorney General William Barr tried to fire the U.S. attorney in Manhattan, Geoffrey Berman, but he is refusing to leave.
content: The top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, who has investigated President Trump’s closest associates, was refusing to leave his position on Saturday after Attorney General William P. Barr tried to fire him, setting up an extraordinary standoff over the independence of law enforcement and the president’s purge of officials he views as disloyal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: ‘Exploding Whale’ Park Memorializes Blubber Blast 50 Years Later
description: Residents of a coastal Oregon city voted to name a park for a 1970 explosion that rained chunks of rotting whale flesh on curious bystanders.
content: Fifty years ago, a whale carcass washed ashore near Florence, Ore., and the authorities wrestled with how to get rid of it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Six Literary Dads for Father’s Day
description: Here are six memorable — though not always in a good way — dads from literature.
content: Here are six memorable — though not always in a good way — dads from literature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Cusumano
title: How to Make a Mini-Golf Course
description: PVC pipe, cardboard boxes, even bobblehead dolls can all be part of a backyard nine.
content: On an unseasonably warm day about a week into the coronavirus shutdown, Elena Delle Donne — a star player for the Washington Mystics of the W.N.B.A., Olympic gold medalist in basketball and avid golfer — and her wife, Amanda, were musing about how nice it would be if golf courses were open. A short time later, Ms. Delle Donne emerged from a basement workout to find that Amanda had built an intricate mini-golf course in their Alexandria, Va., front yard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Pushing for Serbia-Kosovo Peace Deal, U.S. Roils Allies
description: Upending American policy, the Trump Administration is sidelining the E.U., pressuring Kosovo and ignoring Serbia’s erosion of democracy.
content: BERLIN — Last October, with the Balkans unsettled and the old tethers of American diplomacy coming apart, the Trump administration dispatched a new envoy to try to solve one of Europe’s longest-running territorial disputes: the two-decade standoff between Serbia and Kosovo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Trump the Troglodyte
description: The Supremes smack down a prehistoric president.
content: There are leaders who are ahead of their times, leaders who are behind their times, and then there’s Donald Trump, who comes from another time altogether. He’s stuck somewhere closer to the Stone Age than to Stonewall. And the Supreme Court just told him so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: Six Literary Dads for Father’s Day
description: Here are six memorable — though not always in a good way — dads from literature.
content: Here are six memorable — though not always in a good way — dads from literature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: The PGA Tour Resumed Last Week. A Golfer Has Now Tested Positive for the Coronavirus.
description: Nick Watney is the first golfer, caddie or tour official to test positive. Nearly 1,000 tests have been administered for the virus since the PGA Tour returned last week.
content: The PGA Tour expanded coronavirus testing of players, caddies and officials this weekend after five-time tour winner Nick Watney became the first golfer to test positive for the virus since golf’s tournament schedule resumed last week following a three-month layoff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Carlos Ruiz Zafón, Author of ‘The Shadow of the Wind,’ Dies at 55
description: A story within a story that begins in a mysterious place known as the Cemetery of Forgotten Books, it is one of the most successful Spanish novels ever published.
content: MADRID — Carlos Ruiz Zafón, whose mystery novel “The Shadow of the Wind” became one of the best-selling Spanish books of all time, died on Friday at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 55.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manny Fernandez and Mike Baker
title: 1 Dead and 1 Injured After Gunfire in Seattle’s ‘Autonomous Zone’
description: Medics in the protester-run zone treated the victims before they were transported to a hospital. Some protesters objected to the arrival of officers in riot gear.
content: One person died and another was critically injured by gunfire early Saturday morning inside a portion of a Seattle neighborhood that has been occupied by protesters for more than a week, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: ‘Into the Wild’ Bus Air Lifted in Alaska
description: An abandoned bus in the Alaska wilderness, known from the book and the movie “Into the Wild,” was removed by the Alaska Army National Guard on Thursday.
content: An abandoned bus in the Alaska wilderness, known from the book and the movie “Into the Wild,” was removed by the Alaska Army National Guard on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: So You Got a New Bike. Where Are You Supposed to Store It?
description: Your apartment hasn’t gotten any bigger, and you need to store your bike without making the place unlivable. Here are some options.
content: Q: My boyfriend wants to get a bike because he’s worried about riding the subway during the pandemic. But we rent an alcove studio in Brooklyn and we have so little space. I cannot imagine how we’d store a bike. Can we store it in the hallway?
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Sleeping Like a Baby’ Is a Lie
description: Father’s Day essays by Mike Birbiglia and more.
content: Tomorrow is Father’s Day! And we have three personal essays about fatherhood this week to help celebrate the dads in your life. There’s one from Kevin Powell, who has written a beautiful letter to the child he hopes to have. The piece is about how to survive in a world filled with fear, violence, sexism and racism. We have Mike Birbiglia, writing about how he, a sleepwalker, and his wife, J. Hope Stein, an insomniac, had a baby… who also didn't sleep. “There’s an expression, 'sleep like a baby,’ which I thought meant ‘deeply,’ but apparently means ‘doesn’t,’" Birbiglia writes. And we have Erik Vance, an NYT Parenting staff editor, telling us how he feared that fatherhood would make him lose his edge after spending his young adult life as a journalist, adventurer and explorer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Maker of Eskimo Pie Ice Cream Will Retire ‘Inappropriate’ Name
description: As worldwide demonstrations denounce racism, the company behind the nearly 100-year-old frozen treat said it was time to rename a brand considered culturally insensitive.
content: The name attached to Eskimo Pie, the chocolate-covered ice cream treat that has been around for nearly a century, will soon be retired in what is the latest product to yield to growing pressure to remove or rethink brands that have long been considered racist or culturally insensitive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Boyer-Dry
title: The Nutcracker Hustle: Why Selling Bootleg Cocktails Just Got Harder
description: The pandemic has inspired restaurants and bars to mimic the drink. But they have legal protection to do so.
content: Memorial Day Weekend was always a blowout for Amseshem Foluké, a seasonal nutcracker seller.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: ‘Into the Wild’ Bus, Seen as a Danger, Is Airlifted From the Alaskan Wild
description: The Alaska Army National Guard transported the bus to a “secure site” after two hikers have died and at least 15 have had to be rescued while trying to reach the bus in the remote Alaskan wilderness.
content: It was known as “Bus 142” and the “Magic Bus,” and the rusty green-and-white vehicle had exerted a dangerous and almost talismanic power over hikers for nearly a quarter century — ever since the book “Into the Wild” immortalized Christopher McCandless’s solitary odyssey and lonely death in the Alaskan outback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Shaw
title: A Long Night of ‘Flower Flashing’ With Lewis Miller
description: The New York florist beloved for his botanical street installations is reanimating the slowly reopening city.
content: It was 3:37 a.m. on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn when Lewis Miller let out a sigh of relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malcolm Burnley
title: Author Brittney Cooper on Harnessing Rage, Right Now
description: The writer of ‘Eloquent Rage’ discusses the shared anger of black women in the nationwide protests for racial justice.
content: — Brittney Cooper, author of “Eloquent Rage,” on the recent protests
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: CrossFit Owner Fostered Sexist Company Culture, Workers Say
description: Women report getting lewd assessments of their bodies, among other mistreatment from top male management.
content: When Greg Glassman resigned earlier this month as chief executive of CrossFit, Inc., excoriated for comments about George Floyd’s death on Twitter and in a Zoom meeting, people who have worked there were surprised that his downfall was tied to accusations of racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Good Cops, Bad Cops
description: On Father’s Day, I want to tell my dad something I neglected to mention.
content: I never told my father I was proud of him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Astead W. Herndon
title: Waiting for Trump: Hats, Flags, Little Fear of the Virus
description: Supporters waiting to attend President Trump’s return to the campaign trail displayed their loyalty to him, though there were empty seats as the program started.
content: TULSA, Okla. — Public health experts issued dire warnings. Local officials expressed unease. The coronavirus cases continued to climb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: ‘This Is a Change Election’: Will 2 Entrenched House Members Fall?
description: Two candidates who lost to incumbent members of Congress in 2018 are back. An altered political landscape may give them a lift this time.
content: Two years ago, Adem Bunkeddeko and Suraj Patel were part of a crop of young New York Democrats who tried to ride the wave of insurgency that formed after President Trump’s election to victory over longtime House incumbents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Russians Eat Burgers in Gloves. Should Everyone?
description: Status-conscious fast-food joints across Eastern Europe have offered their diners disposable gloves for years. The idea may find a wider audience in the pandemic era.
content: MOSCOW — When you enter a home in Moscow, you take off your shoes. When you go to a play, you have to check your coat. When you eat a burger, you often wear gloves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: China’s Man in Washington, Named Trump
description: Our president is bolstering a nation, but it’s not the United States.
content: “Nobody has been tougher on China than me,” President Trump has declared repeatedly, and he is trying to exploit anti-China feelings for his re-election. He portrays Joe Biden as soft on China, and his backers have run ads denouncing “Beijing Biden.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Tiz the Law Wins an Unusual Belmont Stakes
description: Tiz the Law is a New York-bred colt owned by Sackatoga Stable and trained by the 82-year-old Barclay Tagg.
content: Life is strange these days. We wear face masks, stand six feet apart, and have reluctantly become experts at video conferencing into meetings. Sports are trying to come back in stutter-steps. So it was kind of nice, if even normal, to watch the racehorse Tiz the Law turn in a transcendent performance in the 152nd running of the Belmont Stakes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley and Hisako Ueno
title: Why Japan’s Jobless Rate Is Just 2.6% While the U.S.’s Has Soared
description: A mix of social, demographic and epidemiological factors has kept unemployment down even as the coronavirus has damaged the country’s already weakened economy.
content: TOKYO — When the coronavirus hit Japan, Mari Nagata, a single mother who works in a restaurant, had a lot of worries. Her children’s school closed, and she feared what would happen to them if she got sick.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Gillis and Heather Thompson
title: Take Back the Streets From the Automobile
description: With people hunkered down at home, cities should act quickly to find a better balance between cars and pedestrians and cyclists.
content: Since cities came to exist 5,000 years ago, epidemics have shaped their fate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Mitra Taj
title: Latin America’s Virus Villains: Corrupt Officials Collude With Price Gougers for Body Bags and Flimsy Masks
description: The coronavirus has devastated Latin America. And it has only been worsened by a wave of graft and profiteering, prosecutors say.
content: Of all the schemes that have siphoned resources from Latin American countries fighting the coronavirus, the body bag conspiracy might be the most brazen.
source.name: The New York Times
